Hello Everyone,

As we mentioned on Friday, we want to offer a more granular look at a few of our new policies and procedures relating to our implementation of the State's "MI Safe Return to School" plan's many regulations and requirements. On Friday, we looked at busing, and today we're going to more closely examine the protocols for breakfast, lunch, and recess. We absolutely understand that students need time during the school day to socialize, relax, and have some fun and we were able to preserve all of that while also limiting the number of grade levels that are in any one locale at any one time. Breakfast posed the greatest challenge, as we have all grade levels eating at the same time (as opposed to lunch, where students eat on a staggered schedule according to grade level) but we feel we have reached a workable solution. There are of course no perfect answers that keep everything exactly the same as in years past, but we do feel our plans allow time for kids to be kids without compromising their safety.

Our new schedules are attached below.

Thanks everyone!

I just wanted to take a moment this morning to extend my most sincere and heartfelt thanks to our teaching staff for “Teacher Appreciation Week”. To say that you folks go above and beyond in your service and dedication to our kids would be a severe understatement. Rather, your dedication, compassion, and generosity towards our students seems to know no bounds. I see it from all of you every single day, and I just can’t tell you what a privilege it is for me to be in a position where I can witness all that you do. And I very much mean that literally. After ten years in this position, you still continue to amaze me on a daily basis. It is an honor to work alongside all of you, and I simply can’t thank you enough for all that you do.

--Adam Cocco

Hello,

Thanks to a very generous donation of new, tegular ceiling tiles from Mr. Bob Cooper, owner of Integrity Interiors, a construction company based in Lansing, we are in the process of updating our ceiling in the "horseshoe hallway" portion of our building that starts at our main entrance and wraps around past our cafeteria.. post_text: Ms. Kittaka’s 8th-10th grade science classes conducted experiments last week in which they took a shallow pan of milk and added a few drops of food coloring to see what happened. In 8th grade, students are talking about contact and non-contact forces so this lab helped display what happens when we alter the behavior of polar and non-polar molecules within the milk. In 9th grade biology, students have been learning about the cell membrane, which is made up of polar and non-polar molecules. This lab helps demonstrates what happens when you try to combine the two types of molecules and further explains how the cell membrane functions. In 10th grade chemistry, students have been learning about mixtures, what makes up different kinds of mixtures, and how they can separate the different components. Since milk is a mixture of water, fat, proteins, and other nutrients, this lab is a great example of how the different components of a mixture can act. Keep up the great work!

post_text: Mrs. Casanova's 1st grade class was busy learning sums of 10. This is an important stepping stone in first grade math! Learning to recognize these "10 friends" helps them to understand the "make a ten" strategy, which they will need to know later on. Students play this game like the Memory game, but, instead of finding cards that match, they find "10 Friends". The "10 Friends" are: 9+1, 8+2, 7+3, 6+4, and 5+5. This game can easily be played at home! Keep up the great work 1st graders!

Our team, which is only in its fourth year of existence, narrowly missed making the playoffs and finished the year with a record of four wins and five losses. It's well worth noting that four of those five losses came against teams that are ranked among the top ten in the State.

Congratulations to our Varsity football players and coaches on a fantastic season!

post_text: Mrs. Carter's fourth graders worked together on some STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math) activities at the beginning of the year to get familiar with each other and to learn how to work together to solve problems. The students really enjoyed these activities and look forward to being able to do some more throughout the year. Some of the activities were "Stack the Cup" challenge, "Save Fred" challenge, "Paper Chain" challenge, and "The spaghetti and marshmallow" Challenge. Each activity was of varying difficulty. Some groups were able to combine their thoughts and procedures to complete the task quickly and other took a little more thought and were eventually successful. Although the students thought the best part was eating the gummie worm and gummie ring, the successful part was learning how to work together to decide what is the best course of action to solving each problem. Keep up the good work fourth graders!

post_text: Ms. Kittaka’s Science 8 class just finished a project that required them to construct a car. The students were allowed to build their car however they wanted, the only criteria they had was that it had to move on its own. They spent two weeks building and testing their cars before demonstrating them to the class. They also wrote a report at the end of the project describing the scientific principles that went into building their cars and the simple machines they used. The students brought in most of their own materials and each group came up with a unique car design. Some student designs included Mentos and coke, wind power via balloons, and motors from mini table top fans that the students tore apart. Keep up the good work Ms. Kittaka and 8th grade!

post_text: In Mrs. Jokela’s Algebra 1 class, students just completed a project on population growth. Students modeled population growth by starting with an initial population of two M&Ms in a small container. Students were then instructed to shake the containers, count all M&Ms in which the M was facing up, and then add that number of new M&Ms to the population. A total of 12 trials were conducted by each group of students. This activity was a fun, and interactive, way for students to learn about the real-world applications of population growth and how examples of it are present in their daily lives. Keep up the excellent work, 9th grade!

In a 2008 study, Dr. Roseann Napolitano, Director of School Support at the NYC Department of Education, found that students with involved parents, no matter what their income or background, are more likely to:

- Earn higher grades and test scores, and enroll in higher-
level programs
-Be promoted, pass their classes, and earn credits
-Attend school regularly
-Have better social skills, show improved behavior, and
adapt well to school
-Graduate and go on to post-secondary education

All participants of this course will be entered into a drawing to win prizes and will be provided snacks and refreshments. Please click on the link below and take this short survey so that we are able to gauge interest in this exciting new program.

Thanks in advance for your participation!

-Mr. Depuydt
